43.16: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the man in charge of his house, “Take these men to my house. Butcher an animal, and prepare a meal, because they are going to eat with me at noon.”
43.17: So the man did as Joseph said and took them to Joseph’s house.
43.18: The men were frightened, because they had been brought to Joseph’s house. They thought, “We’ve been brought here because of the money that was put back into our sacks the first time. They’re going to attack us, overpower us, take our donkeys, and make us slaves.”
43.19: So they came to the man in charge of Joseph’s house and spoke to him at the door.
43.20: “Please, sir,” they said, “we came here to buy food once before.
43.21: When we stopped for the night, we opened our sacks, and each man found all of his money inside. So we brought it back with us.
43.22: We also brought more money to buy food. We have no idea who put our money back in our sacks.”
43.23: “It’s alright,” he said. “Don’t be afraid! Your God, the God of your father, must have given you treasure in your sacks. I received your money.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
43.24: The man took the brothers into Joseph’s house. He gave them water to wash their feet and feed for their donkeys.
43.25: They got their gifts ready for Joseph’s return at noon, because they had heard they were going to eat there.
43.26: When Joseph came home, they gave him the gifts they had brought to the house. Then they bowed to him with their faces touching the ground.
43.27: He asked them how they were. Then he said, “You told me about your elderly father. How is he? Is he still alive?”
43.28: They answered, “Yes, sir. Our father is alive and well.” Then they knelt, bowing down.
43.29: As Joseph looked around, he saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son. “Is this your youngest brother, the one you told me about?” he asked. “God be gracious to you, my son,” he said.
43.30: Deeply moved at the sight of his brother, he hurried away, looking for a place to cry. He went into his private room and cried there.
43.31: Then he washed his face and came out. He was in control of his emotions when he said, “Serve the food.”
43.32: He was served separately from his brothers. The Egyptians who were there with him were also served separately, because they found it offensive to eat with Hebrews.
43.33: The brothers were seated facing him according to their ages—from the oldest to the youngest. They looked at each other in amazement.
43.34: Joseph had portions of food brought to them from his table, but Benjamin’s portion was five times more than any of the others. So they ate and drank with Joseph until they were drunk.

44.1:
Joseph commanded the man in charge of his house,
“Fill the men’s sacks with as much food as they can carry. Put each man’s money in his sack.
44.2: Then put my silver cup in the youngest brother’s sack along with the money for his grain.” He did what Joseph told him.
44.3: At dawn the men were sent on their way with their donkeys.
44.4: They had not gone far from the city when Joseph said to the man in charge of his house, “Go after those men at once, and when you catch up with them, say to them, ‘Why have you paid me back with evil when I was good to you?
44.5: Isn’t this the cup that my master drinks from and that he uses for telling the future? What you have done is evil!’ ”
44.6: When he caught up with them, he repeated these words to them.
44.7: They answered him, “Sir, how can you say such things? We would never think of doing anything like that!
44.8: We brought the money we found in our sacks back from Canaan. So why would we steal any silver or gold from your master’s house?
44.9: If one of us has it, he will die, and the rest of us will become your slaves.”
44.10: “I agree,” he said. “We’ll do what you’ve said. The man who has the cup will be my slave, and the rest of you can go free.”
44.11: Each one quickly lowered his sack to the ground and opened it.
44.12: Then the man made a thorough search. He began with the oldest and ended with the youngest. The cup was found in Benjamin’s sack.
44.13: When they saw this, they tore their clothes in grief. Then each one loaded his donkey and went back into the city.
44.14: Judah and his brothers arrived at Joseph’s house while Joseph was still there. Immediately, they bowed with their faces touching the ground.
44.15: Joseph asked them, “What have you done? Don’t you know that a man like me can find things out because he knows the future?”
44.16: “Sir, what can we say to you?” Judah asked. “How else can we explain it? How can we prove we’re innocent? God has uncovered our guilt. Now all of us are your slaves, including the one who had the cup.”
44.17: But Joseph said, “I would never think of doing that! Only the man who had the cup will be my slave. The rest of you can go back to your father in peace.”
44.18: Then Judah went up to Joseph and said, “Please, sir, let me speak openly with you. Don’t be angry with me, although you are equal to Pharaoh.
44.19: Sir, you asked us, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
44.20: We answered, ‘We have a father who is old and a younger brother born to him when he was already old. The boy’s brother is dead, so he’s the only one of his mother’s sons left, and his father loves him.’
44.21: “Then you said to us, ‘Bring him here to me so that I can see him myself.’
44.22: We replied, ‘The boy can’t leave his father. If the boy leaves him, his father will die.’
44.23: Then you told us, ‘If your youngest brother doesn’t come here with you, you will never be allowed to see me again.’
44.24: When we went back to our father, we told him what you had said.
44.25: “Then our father said, ‘Go back and buy us a little more food.’
44.26: We answered, ‘We can’t go back. We can only go back if our youngest brother is with us. The man won’t see us unless our youngest brother is with us.’
44.27: “Then our father said to us, ‘You know that my wife Rachel gave me two sons.
44.28: One is gone, and I said, “He must have been torn to pieces!” I haven’t seen him since.
44.29: If you take this one away from me too and anything happens to him, you’ll drive this gray-haired old man to his grave.’
44.30: “Our father’s life is wrapped up with the boy’s life. If I come home without the boy
44.31: and he sees that the boy isn’t with me, he’ll die. The grief would drive our gray-haired old father to his grave.
44.32: “I guaranteed my father that the boy would come back. I said, ‘If I don’t bring him back to you, then you can blame me the rest of my life, Father.’
44.33: Sir, please let me stay and be your slave in the boy’s place, and let the boy go back with his brothers.
44.34: How could I go back to my father if the boy isn’t with me? I couldn’t bear to see my father’s misery!”

45.1: Joseph could no longer control his emotions in front of everyone who was standing around him, so he cried out, “Have everyone leave me!” No one else was there when Joseph told his brothers who he was.
45.2: He cried so loudly that the Egyptians heard him, and Pharaoh’s household heard about it.
45.3: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still alive?” His brothers could not answer him because they were afraid of him.
45.4: “Please come closer to me,” Joseph said to his brothers. When they did so, he said, “I am Joseph, the brother you sold into slavery in Egypt!
45.5: Now, don’t be sad or angry with yourselves that you sold me. God sent me ahead of you to save lives.
45.6: The famine has been in the land for two years. There will be five more years without plowing or harvesting.
45.7: God sent me ahead of you to make sure that you would have descendants on the earth and to save your lives in an amazing way.
45.8: It wasn’t you who sent me here, but God. He has made me like a father to Pharaoh, lord over his entire household, and ruler of Egypt.
45.9: “Hurry back to my father, and say to him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says, “God has made me lord of Egypt. Come here to me right away!
45.10: Live in the land of Goshen, where you will be near me. Live there with your children and your grandchildren, as well as your flocks, your herds, and everything you have.
45.11: I will provide for you in Egypt, since there will be five more years of famine. Then you, your family, and all who belong to you won’t lose everything.” ’
45.12: “You and my brother Benjamin can see for yourselves that I am the one who is speaking to you.
45.13: Tell my father how greatly honored I am in Egypt and about everything you have seen. Hurry and bring my father here!”
45.14: He threw his arms around his brother Benjamin and cried with Benjamin, who was crying on his shoulder.
45.15: He kissed all his brothers and cried with them. After that his brothers talked with him.
45.16: When Pharaoh’s household heard the news that Joseph’s brothers had come, Pharaoh and his officials were pleased.
45.17: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Say to your brothers, ‘Load up your animals, and go back to Canaan.
45.18: Take your father and your families, and come to me. I will give you the best land in Egypt. Then you can enjoy the best food in the land.’
45.19: “Give them this order: ‘Take wagons with you from Egypt for your children and your wives. Bring your father, and come back.
45.20: Don’t worry about your belongings because the best of everything in Egypt is yours.’ ”
45.21: Israel’s sons did as they were told. Joseph gave them wagons and supplies for their trip as Pharaoh had ordered.
45.22: He gave each of them a change of clothes, but he gave Benjamin three hundred pieces of silver and five changes of clothes.
45.23: He sent his father ten male donkeys carrying Egypt’s best products and ten female donkeys carrying grain, bread, and food for his father’s trip.
45.24: So Joseph sent his brothers on their way. As they were leaving, he said to them, “Don’t quarrel on your way back!”
45.25: So they left Egypt and came to their father Jacob in Canaan.
45.26: They told him, “Joseph is still alive! Yes, he is ruler of Egypt.” Jacob was stunned and didn’t believe them.
45.27: Yet, when they told their father everything Joseph had said to them and he saw the wagons Joseph had sent to bring him back, his spirits were lifted.
45.28: “You have convinced me!” Israel said. “My son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”

46.1: Israel moved with all he had. When he came to Beersheba, he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
46.2:
God spoke to Israel in a vision that night and said, “Jacob, Jacob!”
“Here I am,” he answered.
46.3: “I am God, the God of your father,” he said. “Don’t be afraid to go to Egypt, because I will make you a great nation there.
46.4: I will go with you to Egypt, and I will make sure you come back again. Joseph will close your eyes when you die.”
46.5: So Jacob left Beersheba. Israel’s sons put their father Jacob, their children, and their wives in the wagons Pharaoh had sent to bring him back.
46.6:
They also took their livestock and the possessions they had accumulated in Canaan.
Jacob and all his family arrived in Egypt.
46.7: He had brought his sons, his grandsons, his daughters, and his granddaughters—his entire family.
46.8:
These are the names of Israel’s descendants (Jacob and his descendants) who arrived in Egypt.
Reuben was Jacob’s firstborn.
46.9:
The sons of Reuben were
Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
46.10:
The sons of Simeon were
Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
46.11:
The sons of Levi were
Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
46.12:
The sons of Judah were
Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah. (Er and Onan had died in Canaan.)
The sons of Perez were
Hezron and Hamul.
46.13:
The sons of Issachar were
Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
46.14:
The sons of Zebulun were
Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
46.15: These were the descendants of the sons Leah gave to Jacob in Paddan Aram, in addition to his daughter Dinah. The total number of these sons and daughters was 33.
46.16:
The sons of Gad were
Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
46.17:
The sons of Asher were
Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. Their sister was Serah.
The sons of Beriah were
Heber and Malchiel.
46.18: These were the descendants of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah. She gave birth to these children for Jacob. The total was 16.
46.19:
The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel were
Joseph and Benjamin.
46.20: In Egypt, Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph by Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest from the city of On.
46.21:
The sons of Benjamin were
Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
46.22: These were the descendants of Rachel who were born to Jacob. The total was 14.
46.23:
The son of Dan was
Hushim.
46.24:
The sons of Naphtali were
Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
46.25: These were the descendants of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel. She gave birth to these sons for Jacob. The total was 7.
46.26: The total number of Jacob’s direct descendants who went with him to Egypt was 66. This didn’t include the wives of Jacob’s sons.
46.27: Joseph had two sons who were born in Egypt. The grand total of people in Jacob’s household who went to Egypt was 70.
46.28: Israel sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to get directions to Goshen. When Israel’s family arrived in the region of Goshen,
46.29: Joseph prepared his chariot and went to meet his father Israel. As soon as he saw his father, he threw his arms around him and cried on his shoulder a long time.
46.30: Israel said to Joseph, “Now that I’ve seen for myself that you’re still alive, I’m ready to die.”
46.31: Then Joseph said to his brothers and his father’s family, “I’m going to Pharaoh to tell him, ‘My brothers and my father’s family, who were in Canaan, have come to me.
46.32: The men are shepherds. They take care of livestock. They’ve brought their flocks and herds and everything they own.’
46.33: Now, when Pharaoh calls for you and asks, ‘What kind of work do you do?’
46.34: you must answer, ‘We have taken care of herds all our lives, as our ancestors have done.’ You must say this so that you may live in the region of Goshen, because all shepherds are disgusting to Egyptians.”

47.1: Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father and my brothers have arrived from Canaan with their flocks, herds, and everything they have. Now they are in Goshen.”
47.2: Since he had taken five of his brothers with him, he presented them to Pharaoh.
47.3:
Pharaoh asked the brothers, “What kind of work do you do?”
They answered Pharaoh, “We are shepherds, as were our ancestors.
47.4: We have come to live in this land for a while. The famine is so severe in Canaan that there’s no pasture for our flocks. So please let us live in Goshen.”
47.5: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you.
47.6: All of Egypt is available to you. Have your father and your brothers live in the best part of the land. Let them live in Goshen. If they are qualified, put them in charge of my livestock.”
47.7: Then Joseph brought his father Jacob and had him stand in front of Pharaoh. Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
47.8: Pharaoh asked him, “How old are you?”
47.9: Jacob answered Pharaoh, “The length of my stay on earth has been 130 years. The years of my life have been few and difficult, fewer than my ancestors’ years.”
47.10: Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and left.
47.11: As Pharaoh had ordered, Joseph had his father and his brothers live in the best part of Egypt, the region of Rameses. He gave them property there.
47.12: Joseph also provided his father, his brothers, and all his father’s family with food based on the number of children they had.
47.13: The famine was so severe that there was no food anywhere. Neither Egypt nor Canaan were producing crops because of the famine.
47.14: Joseph collected all the money that could be found in Egypt and in Canaan as payment for the grain people bought. Then he took it to Pharaoh’s palace.
47.15: When the money in Egypt and Canaan was gone, all the Egyptians came to Joseph. “Give us food,” they said. “Do you want us to die right in front of you? We don’t have any more money!”
47.16: Joseph replied, “If you don’t have any more money, give me your livestock, and I’ll give you food  in exchange.”
47.17: So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and he gave them food in exchange for their horses, sheep, goats, cattle, and donkeys. During that year he supplied them with food in exchange for all their livestock.
47.18: When that year was over, they came to him the next year. “Sir,” they said to him, “you know that our money is gone, and you have all our livestock. There’s nothing left to bring you except our bodies and our land.
47.19: Do you want us to die right in front of you? Do you want the land to be ruined? Take us and our land in exchange for food. Then we will be Pharaoh’s slaves and our land will be his property. But give us seed so that we won’t starve to death and the ground won’t become a desert.”
47.20: Joseph bought all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh. Every Egyptian sold his fields because the famine was so severe. The land became Pharaoh’s.
47.21: All over Egypt Joseph moved the people to the cities.
47.22: But he didn’t buy the priests’ land because the priests received an income from Pharaoh, and they lived on that income. That’s why they didn’t sell their land.
47.23: Joseph said to the people, “Now that I have bought you and your land for Pharaoh, here is seed for you. Plant crops in the land.
47.24: Every time you harvest, give one-fifth of the produce to Pharaoh. Four-fifths will be yours to use as seed for your fields and as food for your households.”
47.25: “You have saved our lives,” they said. “Please, sir, we are willing to be Pharaoh’s slaves.”
47.26: Joseph made a law concerning the land in Egypt which is still in force today: One-fifth of the produce belongs to Pharaoh. Only the land of the priests didn’t belong to Pharaoh.
47.27: So the Israelites settled in Egypt in the region of Goshen. They acquired property there and had many children.
47.28: Jacob lived in Egypt 17 years, so he lived a total of 147 years.
47.29: Israel was about to die. He called for his son Joseph and said to him, “I want you to swear that you love me and are faithful to me. Please don’t bury me here.
47.30:
I want to rest with my ancestors. Take me out of Egypt, and bury me in their tomb.”
“I will do as you say,” Joseph answered.
47.31: “Swear to me,” he said. So Joseph swore to him. Then Israel bowed down in prayer with his face at the head of his bed.

48.1: Later Joseph was told, “Your father is ill.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim to see Jacob.
48.2: When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph is here to see you,” Israel gathered his strength and sat up in bed.
48.3: Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in Canaan and blessed me.
48.4: He said to me, ‘I will make you fertile and increase the number of your descendants so that you will become a community of people. I will give this land to your descendants as a permanent possession.’
48.5: “So your two sons, who were born in Egypt before I came here, are my sons. Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine just as Reuben and Simeon are.
48.6: Any other children you have after them will be yours. They will inherit the land listed under their brothers’ names.
48.7: As I was coming back from Paddan, Rachel died in Canaan when we were still some distance from Ephrath. So I buried her there on the way to Ephrath” (that is, Bethlehem).
48.8: When Israel saw Joseph’s sons, he asked, “Who are they?”
48.9:
“They are my sons, whom God has given me here in Egypt,” Joseph answered his father.
Then Israel said, “Please bring them to me so that I may bless them.”
48.10: Israel’s eyesight was failing because of old age, and he could hardly see. So Joseph brought his sons close to his father, and Israel hugged them and kissed them.
48.11: Israel said to Joseph, “I never expected to see you again, and now God has even let me see your sons.”
48.12: Joseph took them off his father’s lap and bowed with his face touching the ground.
48.13: Then Joseph took both of them, Ephraim on his right, facing Israel’s left, and Manasseh on his left, facing Israel’s right, and brought them close to him.
48.14: But Israel crossed his hands and reached out. He put his right hand on Ephraim’s head, although Ephraim was the younger son. He put his left hand on Manasseh’s head, although Manasseh was older.
48.15:
Then Jacob blessed Joseph,
“May God, in whose presence my grandfather Abraham
and my father Isaac walked,
may God, who has been my shepherd all my life to this very day,
48.16:
may the Messenger, who has rescued me from all evil,
bless these boys.
May they be called by my name
and by the names of my grandfather Abraham and my father Isaac.
May they have many children on the earth.”
48.17: When Joseph saw that his father had put his right hand on Ephraim’s head, he didn’t like it. So he took his father’s hand in order to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s.
48.18: Then he said to his father, “That’s not right, Father! This is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head.”
48.19: His father refused and said, “I know, Son, I know! Manasseh, too, will become a nation, and he, too, will be important. Nevertheless, his younger brother will be more important than he, and his descendants will become many nations.”
48.20:
That day he blessed them. He said,
“Because of you, Israel will speak this blessing,
‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh!’ ”
In this way Israel put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
48.21: Then Israel said to Joseph, “Now I’m about to die, but God will be with you. He will bring you back to the land of your fathers.
48.22: I’m giving you one more mountain ridge than your brothers. I took it from the Amorites with my own sword and bow.”

49.1: Jacob called for his sons and said, “Come here, and let me tell you what will happen to you in the days to come.
49.2:
“Gather around and listen, sons of Jacob.
Listen to your father Israel.
49.3:
“Reuben, you are my firstborn,
my strength, the very first son I had,
first in majesty and first in power.
49.4:
You will no longer be first
because you were out of control like a flood
and you climbed into your father’s bed.
Then you dishonored it.
He climbed up on my couch.
49.5:
“Simeon and Levi are brothers.
Their swords are weapons of violence.
49.6:
Do not let me attend their secret meetings.
Do not let me join their assembly.
In their anger they murdered men.
At their whim they crippled cattle.
49.7:
May their anger be cursed because it’s so fierce.
May their fury be cursed because it’s so cruel.
I will divide them among the sons of Jacob
and scatter them among the tribes of Israel.
49.8:
“Judah, your brothers will praise you.
Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies.
Your father’s sons will bow down to you.
49.9:
Judah, you are a lion cub.
You have come back from the kill, my son.
He lies down and rests like a lion.
He is like a lioness. Who dares to disturb him?
49.10:
A scepter will never depart from Judah
nor a ruler’s staff from between his feet
until Shiloh comes
and the people obey him.
49.11:
He will tie his donkey to a grapevine,
his colt to the best vine.
He will wash his clothes in wine,
his garments in the blood of grapes.
49.12:
His eyes are darker than wine.
His teeth are whiter than milk.
49.13:
“Zebulun will live by the coast.
He will have ships by the coast.
His border will go as far as Sidon.
49.14:
“Issachar is a strong donkey,
lying down between the saddlebags.
49.15:
When he sees that his resting place is good
and that the land is pleasant,
he will bend his back to the burden
and will become a slave laborer.
49.16:
“Dan will hand down decisions  for his people
as one of the tribes of Israel.
49.17:
Dan will be a snake on a road,
a viper on a path,
that bites a horse’s heels
so that its rider falls off backwards.
49.18: “I wait with hope for you to rescue me, O Lord.
49.19:
“Gad will be attacked by a band of raiders,
but he will strike back at their heels.
49.20:
“Asher’s food will be rich.
He will provide delicacies fit for a king.
49.21:
“Naphtali is a doe set free
that has beautiful fawns.
49.22:
“Joseph is a fruitful tree,
a fruitful tree by a spring,
with branches climbing over a wall.
49.23:
Archers provoked him,
shot at him,
and attacked him.
49.24:
But his bow stayed steady, and his arms remained limber
because of the help of the Mighty One of Jacob,
because of the name of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
49.25:
because of the God of your father who helps you,
because of the Almighty who gives you
blessings from the heavens above,
blessings from the deep springs below the ground,
blessings from breasts and womb.
49.26:
The blessings of your father are greater than
the blessings of the oldest mountains
and the riches of the ancient hills.
May these blessings rest on the head of Joseph,
on the crown of the prince among his brothers.
49.27:
“Benjamin is a ravenous wolf.
In the morning he devours his prey.
In the evening he divides the plunder.”
49.28: These are the 12 tribes of Israel and what their father said to them when he gave each of them his special blessing.
49.29: Then he gave them these instructions, “I am about to join my ancestors in death. Bury me with my ancestors in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite.
49.30: Abraham bought the cave that is in the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre in Canaan, from Ephron the Hittite to use as a tomb.
49.31: Abraham and his wife Sarah are buried there. Isaac and his wife Rebekah are buried there. I also buried Leah there.
49.32: The field and the cave in it were bought from the Hittites.”
49.33: When Jacob finished giving these instructions to his sons, he pulled his feet into his bed. He took his last breath and joined his ancestors in death.

50.1: Joseph threw himself on his father, cried over him, and kissed him.
50.2: Then Joseph ordered the doctors in his service to embalm his father. So the doctors embalmed Israel.
50.3: The embalming was completed in the usual time—40 days. The Egyptians mourned for him 70 days.
50.4: When the time of mourning for Jacob was over, Joseph spoke to the Pharaoh’s palace staff. He said, “Please speak directly to Pharaoh. Tell him,
50.5: ‘My father made me swear an oath. He said, “I’m about to die. Bury me in the tomb I bought for myself in Canaan.” Please let me go there and bury my father; then I’ll come back.’ ”
50.6: Pharaoh replied, “Go and bury your father, as you have promised him.”
50.7: So Joseph left to bury his father. All Pharaoh’s officials, the leaders in his palace staff, and all the leaders of Egypt went with him.
50.8: Joseph’s household, his brothers, and his father’s household also went with him. (Only their children, their flocks, and their cattle were left in Goshen.)
50.9: Chariots and horsemen went with him. It was a very large group.
50.10: When they came to the threshing floor  of Atad, which is on the east side of the Jordan River, they began a great and solemn ceremony to mourn Jacob’s death. Joseph took seven days to mourn his father’s death.
50.11: When the Canaanites living there saw the funeral ceremonies at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “These funeral ceremonies are taken very seriously by the Egyptians.” That’s why that place on the east side of the Jordan was named Abel Mizraim [Egyptian Funeral Ceremonies].
50.12: Jacob’s sons did for him what he had told them to do.
50.13: They carried him back to Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre. Abraham had bought this tomb from Ephron the Hittite.
50.14: After Joseph had buried his father, he went back to Egypt along with his brothers and everyone who had gone there with him to bury his father.
50.15: Joseph’s brothers realized what their father’s death could mean. So they thought, “What if Joseph holds a grudge against us? What if he decides to pay us back for all the evil we did to him?”
50.16: They sent a messenger to Joseph to say, “Before your father died, he commanded us,
50.17: ‘This is what you should say to Joseph, “I’m begging you to forgive the crime and the sin your brothers committed against you. What they did to you was very evil.” ’ So now, please forgive our crime, because we are servants of your father’s God.” Joseph cried when he got their message.
50.18: Then his brothers also came and immediately bowed down in front of him. “We are your slaves!” they said.
50.19: Joseph said to them, “Don’t be afraid! I can’t take God’s place.
50.20: Even though you planned evil against me, God planned good to come out of it. This was to keep many people alive, as he is doing now.
50.21: Don’t be afraid! I will provide for you and your children.” In this way he reassured them, setting their minds at ease.
50.22: Joseph and his father’s family stayed in Egypt. Joseph lived to be 110 years old.
50.23: He saw his grandchildren, Ephraim’s children. Even the children of Machir, son of Manasseh, were adopted by Joseph at birth.
50.24: At last Joseph said to his brothers, “I’m about to die. God will definitely take care of you and take you out of this land to the land he swore with an oath to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
50.25: Joseph made Israel’s sons swear an oath. He said, “God will definitely take care of you. So be sure to carry my bones back with you.”
50.26: Joseph died when he was 110 years old. His body was embalmed and placed in a coffin in Egypt.
